newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Shenzhen shares up at noon, investors wary.
newsitem.headline: Shenzhen shares up at noon, investors wary.

text.p: Shenzhen's A and B share indices staged a modest technical rebound at midday on Friday, but investors were cautious after Thursday's plunges, brokers said.
The foreign currency B share index rose 0.95 points or 0.63 percent to 151.80 on thin turnover of HK$37 million.
The domestic A share index gained 0.85 points or 0.20 percent to 422.99, on low turnover of 3.1 billion yuan.
"The rebound will not be much stronger later today given the thin turnover," an analyst at Central-South Securities said.
"It is very clear that Beijing wants to dampen share prices and investors will be bearish about the markets in the near future," the analyst said.

Beijing on Wednesday announced it would ban state enterprises and listed firms from speculative stock trading, in a move aimed at curbing the inflow of "hot money" into the country's overheated stock markets, according to brokers.
The fresh crackdown sent share prices in Shenzhen and Shanghai into a free fall on Thursday.
"Thursday's sharp falls presaged a bearish trend, and the Shenzhen B share index is seeking support at the 150-point level," an analyst at China Guotai Securities said.
"But it is still too early to judge whether a long-term downward correction has begun as China's economy has been faring well," the Central-South analyst said.
A wait-and-see mood will continue to dominate trading in the afternoon, analysts said.

On the B share market, newcomer Nanjing Posts & Telecommunication 2468.SZ was the most actively traded with volume of 2.8 million shares, rising HK$0.14 or 3.37 percent to HK$4.30. Its issue price on Thursday was HK$2.43 per share.
Nanjing Posts began trading in Shenzhen on Thursday.
On the A share market, Shenzhen Development Bank rebounded 1.66 yuan to 38.30 yuan on volume of 17.8 million shares.
